newsitem.title: FRANCE: Lawyer sets terms on Eurotunnel debt plan.
newsitem.headline: Lawyer sets terms on Eurotunnel debt plan.

text.p: A lawyer for some institutional shareholders in Eurotunnel said in an interview that those she represented would only vote for the group's debt restructuring if creditor banks abandoned 25 percent of the debt and met several other conditions.

Lawyer Sophie L'Helias spelled out her clients' conditions for approving the debt restructuring at a July 10 shareholders' meeting in an interview to be published in Investir weekly on Saturday. An advance copy was supplied to Reuters.

She said other conditions were that Eurotunnel made "clear commitments in figures" on cost reductions and the "pure and simple withdrawal" of the right for banks to substitute shareholders temporarily during the course of the company's operating licence.
L'Helias also said she wanted a new type of share offered to banks, separating their voting rights from those of shareholders so approval by both groups would be required for board appointments.
Eurotunnel's debt restructuring plan requires approval by all of its creditor banks as well as by two-thirds of French shareholders and 75 percent of British shareholders.
